skill.name: react-ui-patterns
skill.description: Modern React UI patterns for loading states, error handling, and data fetching. Use when building UI components, handling async data, or managing UI states.
skill.summary: React patterns for loading states, errors, and forms
skill.author: ChrisWiles

security_audit.summary: This skill is pure documentation teaching React UI patterns. All static findings are false positives from markdown code blocks and metadata references. No executable code, network operations, or security risks present.

content.user_title: Build React UIs with Modern Patterns
content.value_statement: React applications struggle with loading states, error handling, and empty states causing poor user experience. This skill provides battle-tested patterns for managing UI states, form submissions, and async data fetching.
actual_capabilities: Implement proper loading states that prevent UI flashing
Add comprehensive error handling with user feedback
Create empty states for lists and collections
Build form submission flows with validation and loading states
Apply skeleton screens and spinner patterns appropriately
Handle optimistic updates and progressive disclosure
limitations: Focuses on React-specific patterns and may not apply to other frameworks
Assumes familiarity with React hooks and TypeScript
Does not cover backend implementation or API design
Examples use generic component libraries and may need adaptation

use_cases.title: Fix Flashing Loading Spinners
use_cases.description: Apply the loading state decision tree to eliminate UI flashing during data refetches by checking for existing cached data before showing loaders.

use_cases.title: Implement Comprehensive Error Handling
use_cases.description: Add error states and user feedback to all async operations using the error handling hierarchy from inline errors to full error screens.

use_cases.title: Build Better Form Experiences
use_cases.description: Create form submission flows with proper validation, loading states, disabled buttons, and error feedback using the form submission pattern.
use_cases.target_user: UI engineers working on data entry interfaces

prompt_templates.title: Add Loading State to Component
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a loading state to my React component that fetches user data. Make sure it does not flash when refetching.

prompt_templates.title: Implement Error Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Add error handling to this mutation with toast notifications and a retry option. Show errors to users properly.

prompt_templates.title: Create Empty State
prompt_templates.prompt: Add an empty state to this list component with an action button to create the first item.

prompt_templates.title: Build Complete Form Pattern
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this form to follow best practices with validation, loading states, disabled buttons during submission, and proper error display.

output_examples.input: Add a loading state to my component that fetches items
output_examples.output: I will add a proper loading state check. The key is to only show the loading indicator when there is no data available. This prevents the UI from flashing when refetching cached data. I will implement the pattern: check error first, then loading with no data, then empty state, then render the items.

output_examples.input: My form button can be clicked multiple times during submission
output_examples.output: I will fix this by disabling the button during the loading state. The button should have both disabled and isLoading props set to the loading state. This prevents multiple submissions and gives visual feedback to the user that the action is processing.

best_practices: Check for errors first, then loading state with no data condition, then empty state before rendering content
Always disable buttons and form inputs during async operations to prevent duplicate submissions
Surface all errors to users with appropriate UI feedback and provide retry options when possible
anti_patterns: Showing loading spinners when cached data exists causes unnecessary UI flashing
Catching errors and only logging to console leaves users unaware of failures
Allowing buttons to remain enabled during async operations leads to duplicate submissions and race conditions

faq.question: When should I use skeleton screens versus spinners?
faq.answer: Use skeleton screens when the content shape is known like list or card layouts. Use spinners for unknown content shapes like modal actions or button submissions.

faq.question: Why check loading and no data together?
faq.answer: Checking only loading causes the UI to flash spinners during refetches when you already have cached data. The pattern loading and not data prevents this by showing existing content during background updates.

faq.question: How do I handle errors in mutations?
faq.answer: Always provide an onError callback that both logs the error and shows user feedback through toast notifications or error states. Never silently catch errors with only console logging.

faq.question: What is the error handling hierarchy?
faq.answer: Use inline errors for field validation, toast notifications for recoverable errors, error banners for page-level issues with partial data, and full error screens for unrecoverable failures requiring user action.

faq.question: Should every list have an empty state?
faq.answer: Yes, every collection should provide an empty state component that explains why the list is empty and optionally provides an action to add the first item.

faq.question: How do I prevent double submissions on forms?
faq.answer: Set the disabled prop on submit buttons to the loading state. Also set isLoading to show visual feedback. This prevents clicks during submission and communicates the action is processing.
